repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Project to Mitigate the Impact of the Financial Crisis Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Project to
            Mitigate the Impact of the Financial Crisis Project for
            Congo, Democratic Republic of were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the innovative nature of the project, with
            a limited number of key conditions designed to speed up
            sector reforms, building entirely on existing dialogue and
            ongoing bank financed sector operations, allowed the project
            to disburse 63 percent of funds in four months. Usefulness
            of relying on existing structures to implement an emergency
            project. Possibility of targeting funds from payment of the
            government's utility bills. However, the approach does
            not allow attribution of utilization of the funds by the two
            companies and future operations should weigh the objective
            of crisis response against a more clear focus on
            demonstrated impacts on the ground. The system of
            reimbursement of teacher salaries allows verification that
            funds go towards reimbursing the government for services
            actually delivered by teachers. Need for close technical and
            fiduciary support to this type of emergency project to
            assure full respect of compliance with fiduciary needs.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Response to Mitigate Financial Crisis Impact Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency Response
            to Mitigate Financial Crisis Impact Project is to help
            mitigate the immediate and severe impact of the global
            financial crisis on Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC)
            economy by providing short term transitional support to fund
            critical imports and maintain targeted essential services.
            The project consists of the following components: 1)
            essential imports of critical goods and commodities; 2)
            primary and secondary school teachers' salaries; and 3)
            financing State water and electricity bills. The main
            purpose was to address some of the near-term impacts of the
            financial crisis and sustain economic activities until the
            government's policy responses could take effect and
            medium-term donor support could be fully identified. It will
            ensure that economic activities relying on imports can
            continue uninterrupted and protect the functioning of
            essential social and utility services. The closing date,
            which was originally scheduled for March 1, 2010, has been
            extended for five months to ensure that remaining funds are
            fully utilized.

repnme.cdata!:
Congo, Democratic Republic of - Emergency
            Project to Mitigate the Impact of the Financial Crisis Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper provides a grant to
            the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) to finance an
            emergency recovery support to address some of the near-term
            impacts of the current financial crisis and sustain economic
            activities until the government's policy responses can
            take effect and medium-term donor support can be fully
            identified. The Emergency Project to Mitigate the Impact of
            the Financial Crisis (EPMIFC) will finance the short-term
            costs associated with: (i) the import of essential goods and
            commodities, (ii) the salaries of teachers in the primary
            and secondary education sector, and (iii) the State water
            and electricity bills. It would assure that economic
            activities relying on imports can continue uninterrupted and
            protect the functioning of essential social and utility
            services. In line with the Bank's rapid response policy
            on emergencies and crisis, this grant would support measures
            to mitigate or avert the impact of the financial crisis on
            the country's economic activities, and help preserve
            essential services as well as human, institutional, and
            social capital.
